title: Introduction to ggforge
text: ggforge comprehensive visualization framework designed biomedical bioinformatics research. package greatly inspired modified plotthis Panwen Wang, enhancements high-quality biomedical visualizations.

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: üé® 40+ plotting functions üß¨ Specialized biomedical bioinformatics research üéØ Unified API design across functions üåà Extensive color palette collection üîß Intelligent type detection automatic styling üìä Easy multi-panel figure composition

title: Introduction to ggforge
code: # Install from GitHub devtools::install_github("Zaoqu-Liu/ggforge")

title: Introduction to ggforge
code: library(ggforge) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) set.seed(8525)

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: ggforge plotting functions follow consistent pattern:
code: PlotFunction(   data,                    # Input data frame   x, y,                    # Main aesthetics   group_by = NULL,         # Grouping variable   split_by = NULL,         # Split into multiple plots   palette = "Paired",      # Color palette   theme = "theme_ggforge", # Theme   ...                      # Function-specific parameters )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: ggforge automatically detects variable types applies appropriate styling: Continuous: Numeric variables ‚Üí gradient scales Discrete: Factors/characters ‚Üí discrete colors Temporal: Date/DateTime ‚Üí time axis formatting

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Create multi-panel figures easily split_by:
code: LinePlot(..., split_by = "group", combine = TRUE, nrow = 1)

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Visualize relationships two continuous variables:  Key parameters: add_smooth: Add regression line add_stat: Display correlation statistics group_by: Color points group
code: # Create sample data scatter_data <- data.frame(   x = rnorm(100),   y = rnorm(100),   group = sample(c("A", "B", "C"), 100, replace = TRUE) ) scatter_data$y <- scatter_data$y + 0.5 * scatter_data$x  ScatterPlot(   data = scatter_data,   x = "x",   y = "y",   group_by = "group",   palette = "npg",   add_smooth = TRUE,   add_stat = TRUE,   title = "Correlation Analysis",   xlab = "Variable X",   ylab = "Variable Y" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Compare distributions across groups:
code: # Create sample data box_data <- data.frame(   group = rep(c("Control", "Treat1", "Treat2"), each = 40),   value = c(rnorm(40, 10, 2), rnorm(40, 12, 2.5), rnorm(40, 15, 2)) )  BoxPlot(   data = box_data,   x = "group",   y = "value",   palette = "lancet",   add_point = TRUE,   point_alpha = 0.4,   title = "Treatment Effect Comparison",   xlab = "Treatment Group",   ylab = "Expression Level" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Show full distribution shape:
code: ViolinPlot(   data = box_data,   x = "group",   y = "value",   palette = "npg",   add_box = TRUE,   add_point = TRUE,   point_size = 0.8,   point_alpha = 0.4,   title = "Distribution Comparison" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Smooth distribution visualization:
code: DensityPlot(   data = box_data,   x = "value",   group_by = "group",   palette = "npg",   add_rug = TRUE,   title = "Distribution Density",   xlab = "Expression Value" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Summarize data error bars:
code: BarPlot(   data = box_data,   x = "group",   y = "value",   palette = "Set2",   add_errorbar = TRUE,   errorbar_type = "se",   title = "Mean Values with Standard Error",   xlab = "Treatment Group",   ylab = "Mean Expression" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Visualize trends time continuous variables:
code: # Create time series data time_data <- data.frame(   time = rep(1:10, 3),   value = c(     cumsum(rnorm(10, 0.5, 1)),     cumsum(rnorm(10, 0.3, 1)),     cumsum(rnorm(10, 0.7, 1))   ),   group = rep(c("Group A", "Group B", "Group C"), each = 10) )  LinePlot(   data = time_data,   x = "time",   y = "value",   group_by = "group",   palette = "nejm",   add_point = TRUE,   add_smooth = TRUE,   title = "Time Course Analysis",   xlab = "Time Point",   ylab = "Value" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Enrichment analysis crucial interpreting high-throughput biological data.

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Visualize relationships enriched terms based gene overlap:  shows: Nodes represent enriched terms Edges connect terms sharing genes Node size indicates significance Colors distinguish different databases
code: # Load example enrichment data data("enrich_multidb_example")  EnrichNetwork(   data = enrich_multidb_example,   top_term = 20,   layout = "fr",   palette = "Set3",   title = "Enrichment Network Analysis" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Create similarity-based enrichment maps:  Interpretation: Clusters nodes indicate related biological processes Distance reflects similarity terms Useful identifying major functional themes
code: data("enrich_example")  EnrichMap(   data = enrich_example,   top_term = 25,   layout = "fr",   palette = "Spectral",   title = "GO Enrichment Map" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) identifies coordinated changes pre-defined gene sets.

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Overview multiple GSEA results:  Understanding plot: row represents gene set Running enrichment score (RES) shown line plot Normalized enrichment score (NES) shown color Quickly identify /-regulated pathways
code: # Load GSEA example data data("gsea_example")  GSEASummaryPlot(   data = gsea_example,   top_term = 20,   palette = "RdBu",   title = "GSEA Results Overview" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Detailed view specific pathway enrichment:
code: GSEAPlot(   data = gsea_example,   gs = gsea_example$ID[1],   title = gsea_example$Description[1] )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Single-cell RNA-seq reveals cellular heterogeneity unprecedented resolution.

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Visualize cell populations reduced dimensions:  Best practices: Use UMAP t-SNE visualization Color cluster assignments cell types Add labels easier interpretation
code: # Load dimension reduction example data("dim_example")  DimPlot(   data = dim_example,   x = "basis_1",   y = "basis_2",   group_by = "clusters",   palette = "igv",   point_size = 1.5,   add_label = TRUE,   label_insitu = TRUE,   title = "Cell Clustering (UMAP)" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Overlay gene expression dimensionality reduction:
code: # Create feature data dim_example$feature <- rnorm(nrow(dim_example))  FeatureDimPlot(   data = dim_example,   x = "basis_1",   y = "basis_2",   feature = "feature",   palette = "viridis",   point_size = 1.5,   title = "Gene Expression on UMAP" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Visualize cellular dynamics differentiation trajectories:  Velocity plot types: raw: Individual cell velocity vectors grid: Smoothed velocity field stream: Streamline visualization
code: # Prepare embedding matrices embedding <- as.matrix(dim_example[, c("basis_1", "basis_2")]) v_embedding <- as.matrix(dim_example[, c("stochasticbasis_1", "stochasticbasis_2")])  VelocityPlot(   embedding = embedding,   v_embedding = v_embedding,   plot_type = "grid",   title = "RNA Velocity Analysis" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Standard visualization differential expression:  Customization: Adjust cutoffs significance Control number labeled genes Use custom color schemes
code: # Create differential expression data deg_data <- data.frame(   gene = paste0("Gene", 1:500),   log2FC = rnorm(500, 0, 1.5),   pvalue = runif(500, 0, 0.1) ) deg_data$padj <- p.adjust(deg_data$pvalue, method = "BH")  # Add some significant genes sig_up <- sample(1:500, 25) sig_down <- sample(1:500, 25) deg_data$log2FC[sig_up] <- abs(rnorm(25, 2, 0.5)) deg_data$log2FC[sig_down] <- -abs(rnorm(25, 2, 0.5)) deg_data$padj[c(sig_up, sig_down)] <- runif(50, 0, 0.01)  VolcanoPlot(   data = deg_data,   x = "log2FC",   y = "padj",   label_by = "gene",   x_cutoff = 1,   y_cutoff = 0.05,   nlabel = 10,   title = "Differential Expression Analysis",   xlab = "log2 Fold Change",   ylab = "-log10(Adjusted P-value)" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: GWAS QTL mapping visualization:
code: # Create sample GWAS data gwas_data <- data.frame(   chr = rep(paste0("chr", 1:22), each = 500),   pos = rep(1:500, 22) * 1e5,   pvalue = runif(11000, 0, 1) ) gwas_data$pvalue[sample(1:11000, 30)] <- runif(30, 0, 1e-8)  ManhattanPlot(   data = gwas_data,   chr_by = "chr",   pos_by = "pos",   pval_by = "pvalue",   threshold = 5e-8,   title = "Genome-Wide Association Study" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Kaplan-Meier survival curves essential clinical research:  Components: Survival curves confidence intervals Risk table showing numbers risk Log-rank test p-value Customizable time points
code: # Create survival data surv_data <- data.frame(   time = rexp(150, 0.01),   status = sample(0:1, 150, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.4, 0.6)),   risk = sample(c("Low", "High"), 150, replace = TRUE) )  KMPlot(   data = surv_data,   time = "time",   status = "status",   group_by = "risk",   palette = "jco",   add_risktable = TRUE,   add_conf_int = TRUE,   add_pval = TRUE,   title = "Overall Survival Analysis",   xlab = "Time (months)",   ylab = "Survival Probability" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Multivariate survival analysis forest plot:  Key features: Forest plot showing hazard ratios Confidence intervals covariate P-values statistical significance Automatic handling categorical continuous variables
code: # Create sample data with multiple covariates cox_data <- data.frame(   time = rexp(200, 0.01),   event = sample(0:1, 200, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.3, 0.7)),   age = rnorm(200, 60, 10),   gender = sample(c("Male", "Female"), 200, replace = TRUE),   stage = sample(c("I", "II", "III", "IV"), 200, replace = TRUE),   treatment = sample(c("A", "B"), 200, replace = TRUE) )  CoxPlot(   data = cox_data,   time = "time",   event = "event",   vars = c("age", "gender", "stage", "treatment"),   plot_type = "forest",   palette = "nejm",   title = "Cox Proportional Hazards Model" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Enhanced heatmap matrix data:
code: # Create sample matrix set.seed(123) mat <- matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10) rownames(mat) <- paste0("Gene", 1:10) colnames(mat) <- paste0("Sample", 1:10)  Heatmap(   data = mat,   palette = "RdBu",   title = "Gene Expression Heatmap" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Visualize relationships categories:
code: # Create interaction data chord_data <- data.frame(   from = c("CD4 T", "CD8 T", "B cell", "NK", "Monocyte"),   to = c("Fibroblast", "Endothelial", "Fibroblast", "Tumor", "Tumor"),   value = c(15, 20, 10, 25, 18) )  ChordPlot(   data = chord_data,   from = "from",   to = "to",   y = "value",   palette = "Set3",   title = "Cell-Cell Interaction Network" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Visualize set overlaps:
code: # Create gene sets venn_data <- list(   SetA = paste0("Gene", 1:100),   SetB = paste0("Gene", 50:150),   SetC = paste0("Gene", 80:180) )  VennDiagram(   data = venn_data,   palette = "Set2",   title = "Gene Set Overlap" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: ggforge includes extensive color palettes multiple sources: Palette sources: RColorBrewer palettes ggsci journal palettes (Nature, Science, NEJM, Lancet, JAMA, JCO) viridis color scales d3 categorical scales Usage tips: Use colorblind-friendly palettes (viridis, cividis) Match palette data type (sequential vs.¬†categorical) Consider journal requirements

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Create complex multi-panel figures split_by:
code: # Create data with multiple groups multi_data <- data.frame(   x = rep(1:10, 9),   y = rnorm(90, rep(1:3, each = 30), 0.5),   group = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 30),   condition = rep(rep(c("Ctrl", "Treat1", "Treat2"), each = 10), 3) )  LinePlot(   data = multi_data,   x = "x",   y = "y",   group_by = "condition",   split_by = "group",   palette = "nejm",   add_point = TRUE,   combine = TRUE,   nrow = 1 )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Use facet_by within-plot faceting:
code: # Create faceted data facet_data <- data.frame(   x = rep(1:20, 6),   y = rnorm(120) + rep(rep(c(0, 2, 4), each = 20), 2),   condition = rep(c("Cond1", "Cond2"), each = 60),   time = rep(rep(c("Day1", "Day2", "Day3"), each = 20), 2) )  LinePlot(   data = facet_data,   x = "x",   y = "y",   group_by = "condition",   facet_by = "time",   palette = "jco",   add_smooth = TRUE )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: plots support theme customization:
code: # Apply different themes BoxPlot(   data = box_data,   x = "group",   y = "value",   palette = "npg",   theme = "theme_ggforge",   theme_args = list(base_size = 14) )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Always ensure data tidy format: One row per observation One column per variable value cell
code: # Good: Tidy format data_tidy <- data.frame(   sample = rep(c("S1", "S2", "S3"), each = 3),   gene = rep(c("GeneA", "GeneB", "GeneC"), 3),   expression = rnorm(9) )  # Bad: Wide format # data_wide <- data.frame( #   sample = c("S1", "S2", "S3"), #   GeneA = rnorm(3), #   GeneB = rnorm(3), #   GeneC = rnorm(3) # )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Guidelines choosing colors: Colorblind-friendly: Use viridis, cividis, similar Consistency: Use colors categories across figures Contrast: Ensure sufficient contrast readability Journal requirements: Check specific requirements

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Recommended settings saving figures:
code: # High-resolution PDF ggsave(   "figure.pdf",   plot = your_plot,   width = 8,   height = 6,   dpi = 300,   device = "pdf" )  # TIFF for some journals ggsave(   "figure.tiff",   plot = your_plot,   width = 8,   height = 6,   dpi = 600,   device = "tiff",   compression = "lzw" )

title: Introduction to ggforge
text: Always set seed reproducible results:
code: set.seed(8525) # ggforge default seed

title: Introduction to ggforge
code: # Check column names (case-sensitive) colnames(your_data)

what: Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: ggforge comprehensive elegant visualization framework designed biomedical bioinformatics research. Built ggplot2 modern modular architecture, provides 40+ plotting functions covering statistical graphics, enrichment analysis, single-cell transcriptomics, spatial analysis, survival analysis, genomics visualization.

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: Complete documentation available : https://zaoqu-liu.github.io/ggforge Getting Started Tutorial: https://zaoqu-liu.github.io/ggforge/articles/introduction.html Function Reference: https://zaoqu-liu.github.io/ggforge/reference/ GitHub Repository: https://github.com/Zaoqu-Liu/ggforge

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
code: # Install from GitHub if (!require("devtools")) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("Zaoqu-Liu/ggforge")

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
code: library(ggforge) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) set.seed(8525)

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: Box Plots  Violin Plots  Scatter Plots  Density Plots  Bar Plots  Line Plots
code: data <- data.frame(   group = rep(c("Control", "Treatment A", "Treatment B"), each = 50),   value = c(rnorm(50, 10, 2), rnorm(50, 12, 2.5), rnorm(50, 15, 2)) )  BoxPlot(   data = data,   x = "group",   y = "value",   palette = "lancet",   add_point = TRUE,   point_alpha = 0.3,   xlab = "Treatment Group",   ylab = "Expression Level",   title = "Gene Expression Across Treatment Groups" ) ViolinPlot(   data = data,   x = "group",   y = "value",   palette = "npg",   add_box = TRUE,   add_point = TRUE,   point_size = 0.8,   point_alpha = 0.4,   title = "Distribution of Gene Expression" ) n <- 200 scatter_data <- data.frame(   gene_A = rnorm(n, 100, 20),   gene_B = rnorm(n, 100, 20),   cell_type = sample(c("T cell", "B cell", "Monocyte"), n, replace = TRUE) ) scatter_data$gene_B <- scatter_data$gene_B + 0.7 * scatter_data$gene_A + rnorm(n, 0, 10)  ScatterPlot(   data = scatter_data,   x = "gene_A",   y = "gene_B",   group_by = "cell_type",   palette = "jco",   add_smooth = TRUE,   add_stat = TRUE,   xlab = "Gene A Expression",   ylab = "Gene B Expression",   title = "Gene Expression Correlation" ) DensityPlot(   data = data,   x = "value",   group_by = "group",   palette = "npg",   add_rug = TRUE,   xlab = "Expression Value",   title = "Distribution of Gene Expression" ) BarPlot(   data = data,   x = "group",   y = "value",   palette = "Set2",   add_errorbar = TRUE,   errorbar_type = "se",   title = "Mean Values with Standard Error",   xlab = "Treatment Group",   ylab = "Mean Expression" ) time_data <- data.frame(   time = rep(1:10, 3),   value = c(     cumsum(rnorm(10, 0.5, 1)),     cumsum(rnorm(10, 0.3, 1)),     cumsum(rnorm(10, 0.7, 1))   ),   group = rep(c("Group A", "Group B", "Group C"), each = 10) )  LinePlot(   data = time_data,   x = "time",   y = "value",   group_by = "group",   palette = "nejm",   add_point = TRUE,   add_smooth = TRUE,   title = "Time Course Analysis",   xlab = "Time Point",   ylab = "Value" )

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: Enrichment Network  Enrichment Map
code: data("enrich_multidb_example")  EnrichNetwork(   data = enrich_multidb_example,   top_term = 20,   layout = "fr",   palette = "Set3",   title = "Enrichment Network Analysis" ) data("enrich_example")  EnrichMap(   data = enrich_example,   top_term = 25,   layout = "fr",   palette = "Spectral",   title = "GO Enrichment Map" )

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: GSEA Summary Plot  GSEA Enrichment Plot
code: data("gsea_example")  GSEASummaryPlot(   data = gsea_example,   top_term = 20,   palette = "RdBu",   title = "GSEA Analysis Summary" ) GSEAPlot(   data = gsea_example,   gs = gsea_example$ID[1],   title = gsea_example$Description[1] )

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: Dimensionality Reduction  Feature Expression  RNA Velocity
code: data("dim_example")  DimPlot(   data = dim_example,   x = "basis_1",   y = "basis_2",   group_by = "clusters",   palette = "igv",   point_size = 1.2,   add_label = TRUE,   label_insitu = TRUE,   title = "UMAP Clustering" ) dim_example$feature <- rnorm(nrow(dim_example))  FeatureDimPlot(   data = dim_example,   x = "basis_1",   y = "basis_2",   feature = "feature",   palette = "viridis",   point_size = 1.5,   title = "Gene Expression on UMAP" ) embedding <- as.matrix(dim_example[, c("basis_1", "basis_2")]) v_embedding <- as.matrix(dim_example[, c("stochasticbasis_1", "stochasticbasis_2")])  VelocityPlot(   embedding = embedding,   v_embedding = v_embedding,   plot_type = "grid",   title = "RNA Velocity Analysis" )

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: Volcano Plot  Manhattan Plot
code: deg_data <- data.frame(   gene = paste0("Gene", 1:500),   log2FC = rnorm(500, 0, 1.5),   pvalue = runif(500, 0, 0.1) ) deg_data$padj <- p.adjust(deg_data$pvalue, method = "BH")  sig_up <- sample(1:500, 25) sig_down <- sample(1:500, 25) deg_data$log2FC[sig_up] <- abs(rnorm(25, 2, 0.5)) deg_data$log2FC[sig_down] <- -abs(rnorm(25, 2, 0.5)) deg_data$padj[c(sig_up, sig_down)] <- runif(50, 0, 0.01)  VolcanoPlot(   data = deg_data,   x = "log2FC",   y = "padj",   label_by = "gene",   x_cutoff = 1,   y_cutoff = 0.05,   nlabel = 10,   title = "Differential Expression Analysis",   xlab = "log2 Fold Change",   ylab = "-log10(Adjusted P-value)" ) gwas_data <- data.frame(   chr = rep(paste0("chr", 1:22), each = 500),   pos = rep(1:500, 22) * 1e5,   pvalue = runif(11000, 0, 1) ) gwas_data$pvalue[sample(1:11000, 30)] <- runif(30, 0, 1e-8)  ManhattanPlot(   data = gwas_data,   chr_by = "chr",   pos_by = "pos",   pval_by = "pvalue",   threshold = 5e-8,   title = "Genome-Wide Association Study" )

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: Kaplan-Meier Curve  Cox Regression Analysis
code: surv_data <- data.frame(   time = rexp(150, 0.01),   status = sample(0:1, 150, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.4, 0.6)),   risk = sample(c("Low", "High"), 150, replace = TRUE) )  KMPlot(   data = surv_data,   time = "time",   status = "status",   group_by = "risk",   palette = "jco",   add_risktable = TRUE,   add_conf_int = TRUE,   add_pval = TRUE,   title = "Overall Survival Analysis",   xlab = "Time (months)",   ylab = "Survival Probability" ) # Create sample data with multiple covariates cox_data <- data.frame(   time = rexp(200, 0.01),   event = sample(0:1, 200, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.3, 0.7)),   age = rnorm(200, 60, 10),   gender = sample(c("Male", "Female"), 200, replace = TRUE),   stage = sample(c("I", "II", "III", "IV"), 200, replace = TRUE),   treatment = sample(c("A", "B"), 200, replace = TRUE) )  CoxPlot(   data = cox_data,   time = "time",   event = "event",   vars = c("age", "gender", "stage", "treatment"),   plot_type = "forest",   palette = "nejm",   title = "Cox Proportional Hazards Model" )

title: ggforge - Comprehensive Visualization Toolkit for Biomedical Research
text: Heatmap  Chord Diagram  Venn Diagram
code: set.seed(123) mat <- matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10) rownames(mat) <- paste0("Gene", 1:10) colnames(mat) <- paste0("Sample", 1:10)  Heatmap(   data = mat,   palette = "RdBu",   title = "Gene Expression Heatmap" ) chord_data <- data.frame(   from = c("CD4 T", "CD8 T", "B cell", "NK", "Monocyte"),   to = c("Fibroblast", "Endothelial", "Fibroblast", "Tumor", "Tumor"),   value = c(15, 20, 10, 25, 18) )  ChordPlot(   data = chord_data,   from = "from",   to = "to",   y = "value",   palette = "Set3",   title = "Cell-Cell Interaction Network" ) venn_data <- list(   SetA = paste0("Gene", 1:100),   SetB = paste0("Gene", 50:150),   SetC = paste0("Gene", 80:180) )  VennDiagram(   data = venn_data,   palette = "Set2",   title = "Gene Set Overlap" )

title: Area Plot ‚Äî AreaPlot
text: plot showing one groups' numeric values change progression another variable.

title: Area Plot ‚Äî AreaPlot
code: AreaPlot(   data,   x,   y = NULL,   x_sep = "_",   group_by = NULL,   group_by_sep = "_",   group_name = NULL,   scale_y = FALSE,   split_by = NULL,   split_by_sep = "_",   facet_by = NULL,   facet_scales = "fixed",   facet_nrow = NULL,   facet_ncol = NULL,   facet_byrow = TRUE,   theme = "theme_ggforge",   theme_args = list(),   palette = "Paired",   palcolor = NULL,   alpha = 1,   x_text_angle = 0,   aspect.ratio = 1,   legend.position = waiver(),   legend.direction = "vertical",   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   keep_empty = FALSE,   seed = 8525,   combine = TRUE,   nrow = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   byrow = TRUE,   axes = NULL,   axis_titles = NULL,   guides = NULL,   design = NULL,   ... )

title: Area Plot ‚Äî AreaPlot
text: data data frame containing data plot x character string column name plot x-axis. character/factor column expected. y character string column name plot y-axis. numeric column expected. NULL, count x-axis column used. x_sep character string concatenate columns x, multiple columns provided. group_by character vector column names fill area plot . NULL, plot filled first color palette. multiple columns provided, columns concatenated group_by_sep used fill column. group_by_sep character string separate columns group_by. group_name character string name legend fill. scale_y logical value scale y-axis total number x-axis group. split_by Column name(s) split data multiple plots split_by_sep Separator concatenating multiple split_by columns facet_by Column name(s) faceting plot facet_scales Scales facets: "fixed", "free", "free_x", "free_y" facet_nrow Number rows facet layout facet_ncol Number columns facet layout facet_byrow Fill facets row (TRUE) column (FALSE) theme Theme name (string) theme function theme_args List arguments passed theme function palette Color palette name palcolor Custom colors palette alpha Transparency level (0-1) x_text_angle Angle x-axis text aspect.ratio Aspect ratio plot panel legend.position Legend position: "none", "left", "right", "bottom", "top" legend.direction Legend direction: "horizontal" "vertical" title Plot title subtitle Plot subtitle xlab X-axis label ylab Y-axis label keep_empty Whether keep empty factor levels seed Random seed reproducibility combine Whether combine split plots one nrow Number rows combining plots ncol Number columns combining plots byrow Fill combined plots row axes handle axes combined plots ("keep", "collect", "collect_x", "collect_y") axis_titles handle axis titles combined plots guides handle guides combined plots ("collect", "keep", "auto") design Custom layout design combined plots

title: Area Plot ‚Äî AreaPlot
text: ggplot object wrap_plots object list ggplot objects

title: Area Plot ‚Äî AreaPlot
code: data <- data.frame(   x = rep(c("A", "B", "C", "D"), 2),   y = c(1, 3, 6, 4, 2, 5, 7, 8),   group = rep(c("F1", "F2"), each = 4),   split = rep(c("X", "Y"), 4) ) AreaPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", group_by = "group")  AreaPlot(data,   x = "x", y = "y", group_by = "group",   scale_y = TRUE )  AreaPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "group")  AreaPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "group", palette = c(F1 = "Blues", F2 = "Reds"))  AreaPlot(data,   x = "x", y = "y", group_by = "group", split_by = "split",   legend.direction = c(X = "horizontal", Y = "vertical"),   legend.position = c(X = "top", Y = "right") )

title: Bar Plot ‚Äî BarPlot
text: ggplot object, list plots, combined plots

title: Bar Plot ‚Äî BarPlot
code: # \donttest{ # Simple bar plot (counts) data <- data.frame(   category = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "A", "B") ) BarPlot(data, x = "category")   # Bar plot with values data <- data.frame(   category = c("A", "B", "C", "D"),   value = c(10, 15, 8, 12) ) BarPlot(data, x = "category", y = "value")   # Grouped bar plot (dodged) data <- data.frame(   category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), 2),   value = c(10, 15, 8, 12, 18, 14),   group = rep(c("G1", "G2"), each = 3) ) BarPlot(data, x = "category", y = "value", group_by = "group")   # Stacked bar plot BarPlot(data, x = "category", y = "value", group_by = "group", position = "stack")   # With labels and customization BarPlot(   data,   x = "category", y = "value", group_by = "group",   label = TRUE, palette = "Set2", flip = TRUE )   # With splits (multiple plots) data$experiment <- rep(c("Exp1", "Exp2"), 3) BarPlot(data, x = "category", y = "value", split_by = "experiment")   # With faceting (single plot, multiple panels) BarPlot(data, x = "category", y = "value", facet_by = "experiment")  # }

title: Box Plot ‚Äî BoxPlot
text: ggplot object combined plots (patchwork)

title: Box Plot ‚Äî BoxPlot
code: # \donttest{ # ============================================================ # Basic Examples # ============================================================  # Create sample data set.seed(123) data <- data.frame(   group = rep(LETTERS[1:4], each = 25),   value = c(     rnorm(25, 10, 2), rnorm(25, 12, 2),     rnorm(25, 11, 3), rnorm(25, 14, 2)   ),   treatment = rep(c("Control", "Treatment"), 50),   gender = sample(c("Male", "Female"), 100, replace = TRUE) )  # Simple box plot BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value")   # Box plot with custom labels BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   title = "Distribution by Group",   xlab = "Experimental Group",   ylab = "Measurement Value" )   # ============================================================ # Grouped Box Plots # ============================================================  # Side-by-side (dodged) box plots by treatment BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value", group_by = "treatment")   # With custom group legend name BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   group_by = "treatment",   group_name = "Treatment Group" )   # With custom color palette BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   group_by = "treatment",   palette = "Set1" )   # ============================================================ # Adding Data Points # ============================================================  # Add jittered points to show individual observations BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value", add_point = TRUE)   # Customize point appearance BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   add_point = TRUE,   pt_color = "darkblue",   pt_size = 1.5,   pt_alpha = 0.6 )   # With grouped data BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   group_by = "treatment",   add_point = TRUE,   pt_alpha = 0.5 )   # ============================================================ # Highlighting Specific Points # ============================================================  # Highlight outliers or specific observations BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   add_point = TRUE,   highlight = "value > 15",   highlight_color = "red",   highlight_size = 3 )   # Highlight by row indices BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   add_point = TRUE,   highlight = c(1, 5, 10, 15),   highlight_color = "orange" )   # ============================================================ # Statistical Comparisons # ============================================================  # Compare specific pairs BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   comparisons = list(c("A", "B"), c("A", "D")) )   # Compare all pairs BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   comparisons = TRUE )   # Use t-test instead of Wilcoxon BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   comparisons = list(c("A", "D")),   pairwise_method = "t.test" )   # Show significance symbols instead of p-values BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   comparisons = TRUE,   sig_label = "p.signif" )   # Hide non-significant comparisons BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   comparisons = TRUE,   hide_ns = TRUE )   # With grouped data - compare groups within each x category BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   group_by = "treatment",   comparisons = TRUE )   # Multiple group comparison (Kruskal-Wallis) BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   multiplegroup_comparisons = TRUE )   # ============================================================ # Paired Data Analysis # ============================================================  # Create paired data (before/after measurements) paired_data <- data.frame(   time = factor(rep(c("Before", "After"), each = 20)),   subject = factor(rep(1:20, 2)),   score = c(rnorm(20, 50, 10), rnorm(20, 55, 10)) )  # Paired box plot with connecting lines BoxPlot(paired_data,   x = "time", y = "score",   paired_by = "subject",   add_point = TRUE )   # With paired statistical test BoxPlot(paired_data,   x = "time", y = "score",   paired_by = "subject",   comparisons = list(c("Before", "After")),   pairwise_method = "t.test" ) #> Warning: Forcing 'add_point' = TRUE when 'paired_by' is provided.   # ============================================================ # Sorting and Orientation # ============================================================  # Sort by mean value (ascending) BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value", sort_x = "mean_asc")   # Sort by median value (descending) BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value", sort_x = "median_desc")   # Horizontal box plot BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value", flip = TRUE)   # ============================================================ # Axis Customization # ============================================================  # Set y-axis limits BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   y_min = 5, y_max = 20 )   # Use quantiles for y-axis limits (exclude extreme values) BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   y_min = "q5", y_max = "q95" )   # Log-transform y-axis pos_data <- data pos_data$value <- abs(pos_data$value) + 1 BoxPlot(pos_data,   x = "group", y = "value",   y_trans = "log10" )   # ============================================================ # Visual Enhancements # ============================================================  # Add trend line connecting medians BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value", add_trend = TRUE)   # Add reference line BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   add_line = 12,   line_color = "red",   line_type = 2 )   # Add alternating background BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   add_bg = TRUE,   bg_alpha = 0.1 )   # Add mean indicator BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   add_stat = mean,   stat_name = "Mean",   stat_color = "red",   stat_shape = 18 )   # ============================================================ # Faceting # ============================================================  # Facet by another variable BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   facet_by = "gender" )   # Control facet layout BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   facet_by = "gender",   facet_ncol = 2 )   # Free y-axis scales per facet BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   facet_by = "gender",   facet_scales = "free_y" )   # ============================================================ # Fill Modes # ============================================================  # Fill by x-axis category (default when no group_by) BoxPlot(data, x = "group", y = "value", fill_mode = "x")   # Fill by mean value (gradient) BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   fill_mode = "mean",   palette = "RdYlBu" )   # Fill by median value (gradient) BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   fill_mode = "median",   palette = "viridis" )   # ============================================================ # Wide Format Data # ============================================================  # Wide format: each column is a group wide_data <- data.frame(   GroupA = rnorm(30, 10, 2),   GroupB = rnorm(30, 12, 2),   GroupC = rnorm(30, 11, 3) )  BoxPlot(wide_data,   x = c("GroupA", "GroupB", "GroupC"),   in_form = "wide" )   # ============================================================ # Splitting into Multiple Plots # ============================================================  # Create separate plots by a variable BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   split_by = "gender",   combine = TRUE,   ncol = 2 )   # ============================================================ # Theme and Style Customization # ============================================================  # Custom color palette BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   palette = "Dark2" )   # Custom colors BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   palcolor = c(     "A" = "#E41A1C", "B" = "#377EB8",     "C" = "#4DAF4A", "D" = "#984EA3"   ) )   # Legend position BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   group_by = "treatment",   legend.position = "bottom",   legend.direction = "horizontal" )   # Hide legend BoxPlot(data,   x = "group", y = "value",   group_by = "treatment",   legend.position = "none" )  # }

code: # Basic correlation plot with grouping data(iris) CorPlot(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Sepal.Width", group_by = "Species")   # With custom annotations and positioning CorPlot(iris,   x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Sepal.Width",   group_by = "Species",   anno_items = c("n", "eq", "r2", "pearson"),   anno_position = "bottomright" )   # With highlighting specific points CorPlot(iris,   x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Sepal.Width",   group_by = "Species",   highlight = 'Species == "setosa"',   highlight_color = "red",   highlight_size = 3,   highlight_stroke = 1.5 )   # With faceting by groups CorPlot(iris,   x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Sepal.Width",   facet_by = "Species",   facet_scales = "free",   add_smooth = TRUE,   smooth_color = "blue" )   # With splitting and custom palettes CorPlot(iris,   x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Sepal.Width",   split_by = "Species",   palette = c(setosa = "Set1", versicolor = "Dark2", virginica = "Paired"),   combine = TRUE )   # For large datasets, use raster mode if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ CorPlot(large_data,   x = "x_var", y = "y_var",   raster = TRUE,   raster_dpi = c(1024, 1024),   pt_size = 1 ) } # }

title: Dimension Reduction Plot ‚Äî DimPlot
text: data data frame containing data plot dims Column names indices x y axes. Default first two columns. group_by Column name categorical grouping. Creates discrete color mapping. multiple columns provided, concatenated group_by_sep. group_by_sep Separator concatenating multiple group_by columns. split_by Column name(s) split data multiple plots split_by_sep Separator concatenating multiple split_by columns pt_size Point size. NULL, calculated based number data points. pt_alpha Point transparency (0-1). bg_color Color NA/background points. label Whether show group labels median positions. label_insitu Whether use actual group names labels (vs. numbers). label_size Size labels. label_fg, label_bg Foreground background colors labels. label_bg_r Background radius labels. label_repel Whether repel overlapping labels. label_repulsion Repulsion force labels. label_pt_size, label_pt_color Point size color label anchors. label_segment_color Color segments connecting labels points. show_stat Whether show sample count subtitle. order order points: "-", "reverse", "high-top", "low-top", "random". Affects drawing order (top). highlight Row names/indices highlight, logical expression string. highlight_alpha, highlight_size, highlight_color, highlight_stroke Styling highlighted points. add_mark Whether add marks (hulls/ellipses) around groups. mark_type Type mark: "hull", "ellipse", "rect", "circle". mark_expand, mark_alpha, mark_linetype Mark styling parameters. add_density Whether add 2D density contours/fill. density_color, density_filled Density styling. density_filled_palette, density_filled_palcolor Palette filled density. raster Whether rasterize points (useful large datasets). raster_dpi DPI rasterization. hex Whether use hexagonal binning instead points. hex_linewidth, hex_count, hex_bins, hex_binwidth Hex bin parameters. facet_by Column name(s) faceting plot facet_scales Scales facets: "fixed", "free", "free_x", "free_y" facet_nrow Number rows facet layout facet_ncol Number columns facet layout facet_byrow Fill facets row (TRUE) column (FALSE) theme Theme name (string) theme function theme_args List arguments passed theme function palette Color palette name palcolor Custom colors palette alpha Transparency level (0-1) aspect.ratio Aspect ratio plot panel legend.position Legend position: "none", "left", "right", "bottom", "top" legend.direction Legend direction: "horizontal" "vertical" title Plot title subtitle Plot subtitle xlab X-axis label ylab Y-axis label keep_empty Keep empty factor levels seed Random seed reproducibility combine Whether combine split plots one nrow Number rows combining plots ncol Number columns combining plots byrow Fill combined plots row axes handle axes combined plots ("keep", "collect", "collect_x", "collect_y") axis_titles handle axis titles combined plots guides handle guides combined plots ("collect", "keep", "auto") design Custom layout design combined plots

Either "ellipse", "rect", "circle", "text" mark functions ggforce. label character string specifying label show legend. values_by = "z-score",     show_row_names = TRUE, show_column_names = TRUE,     rows_name = "Features", row_names_side = "left",     columns_name = "Samples"   ) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", title: Jitter Plot ‚Äî JitterPlot
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(8525) n <- 200 x <- sample(LETTERS[1:5], n, replace = TRUE) group <- sample(c("G1", "G2"), n, replace = TRUE) size <- rexp(n, rate = 1) id <- paste0("pt", seq_len(n)) y <- rnorm(n, mean = ifelse(group == "G1", 0.5, -0.5)) +   as.numeric(factor(x, levels = LETTERS[1:5])) / 10 df <- data.frame(   x = factor(x, levels = LETTERS[1:5]),   y = y,   group = group,   size = size,   id = id )  # Basic JitterPlot(df, x = "x", y = "y")   # Map size with transform; legend shows original values JitterPlot(df,   x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "size", size_name = "Abundance",   size_trans = sqrt, order_by = "-y^2" )   # Dodge by group and add a horizontal line JitterPlot(df,   x = "x", y = "y", group_by = "group",   add_hline = 0, hline_type = "dashed", hline_color = "red2" )   # Label top points by distance (y^2 + size^2) JitterPlot(df, x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "size", label_by = "id", nlabel = 3)   # Flip axes JitterPlot(df, x = "x", y = "y", flip = TRUE)  # }

title: Manhattan Plot ‚Äî ManhattanPlot
text: Creates Manhattan plot visualizing genome-wide association study (GWAS) results. function adapted ggmanh::manhattan_plot() several enhancements: Parameter names use underscores instead dots consistency chr.colname, pos.colname, pval.colname label.colname renamed chr_by, pos_by, pval_by label_by chromosome chr.order arguments merged chromosomes highlight.colname argument replaced highlight, can vector indices character expression select variants, instead column name Point styling controlled pt_* arguments (size, color, alpha, shape) Label styling controlled label_* arguments Highlight styling controlled highlight_* arguments Flexible p-value transformation via pval_transform function Improved significance threshold handling

code: # \donttest{ set.seed(1000)  nsim <- 50000  simdata <- data.frame(   "chromosome" = sample(c(1:22, "X"), size = nsim, replace = TRUE),   "position" = sample(1:100000000, size = nsim),   "P.value" = rbeta(nsim, shape1 = 5, shape2 = 1)^7,   "cohort" = sample(c("A", "B"), size = nsim, replace = TRUE) ) simdata$chromosome <- factor(simdata$chromosome, c(1:22, "X"))  if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) {   ManhattanPlot(     simdata,     pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",     title = "Simulated P.Values", ylab = "P"   ) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) {   # split_by   ManhattanPlot(     simdata,     pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",     title = "Simulated P.Values", ylab = "P", split_by = "cohort", ncol = 1   ) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Customized p-value transformation and significance threshold line colors   ManhattanPlot(     simdata,     pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",     title = "Simulated -Log2 P.Values", ylab = "-log2(P)", pval_transform = "-log2",     signif_color = c("red", "blue")   ) }  # }

title: Pie Chart ‚Äî PieChart
code: # Create sample data data <- data.frame(   x = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E", "F", "G", "H"),   y = c(10, 8, 16, 4, 6, 12, 14, 2),   group = c("G1", "G1", "G2", "G2", "G3", "G3", "G4", "G4"),   facet = c("F1", "F2", "F3", "F4", "F1", "F2", "F3", "F4") )  # Basic pie chart PieChart(data, x = "x", y = "y")   # Counter-clockwise PieChart(data, x = "x", y = "y", clockwise = FALSE)   # With labels PieChart(data, x = "x", y = "y", label = "group")   # With faceting PieChart(data, x = "x", y = "y", facet_by = "facet")   # Split by group PieChart(data, x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "group")   # Custom palettes per split PieChart(data,   x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "group",   palette = list(G1 = "Reds", G2 = "Blues", G3 = "Greens", G4 = "Purples") )   # Use counts (y from count) PieChart(data, x = "group")   # With count labels PieChart(data, x = "group", label = ".y")

code: set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(norm = rnorm(100))  QQPlot(data, val = "norm", band = TRUE)  QQPlot(data, val = "norm", band = list(   list(bandType = "ks", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "KS"), alpha = 0.3),   list(bandType = "ts", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "TS")),   list(bandType = "pointwise", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "Normal")),   list(bandType = "boot", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "Bootstrap")) ), band_alpha = 0.6)   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data(airquality, package = "datasets") di <- "exp" # exponential distribution dp <- list(rate = 2) # exponential rate parameter QQPlot(airquality,   val = "Ozone",   band = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp),   line = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp),   point = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp) )  de <- TRUE # enabling the detrend option QQPlot(airquality,   val = "Ozone",   band = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp, detrend = de),   line = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp, detrend = de),   point = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp, detrend = de) )  QQPlot(data, val = "norm", type = "pp", band = TRUE)  dp <- list(mean = 2, sd = 2) # shifted and rescaled Normal parameters QQPlot(data,   val = "norm", type = "pp",   band = list(dparams = dp),   point = list(dparams = dp) )  QQPlot(data,   val = "norm", type = "pp", band = TRUE,   line = list(ab = c(.2, .5)) )  di <- "exp" dp <- list(rate = .022) # value is based on some empirical tests de <- TRUE QQPlot(airquality,   val = "Ozone", type = "pp",   band = list(distribution = di, detrend = de, dparams = dp),   line = list(detrend = de),   point = list(distribution = di, detrend = de, dparams = dp),   ylim = c(-.5, .5) ) } # }

NULL provided, line added. point list arguments pass qqplotr::stat_qq_point() qqplotr::stat_pp_point(), depending value type. Default list(), means add points default arguments. NULL provided, points added (recommended). fill_name character string name legend fill. Default "Bands". band_alpha numeric value set alpha bands. Default 0.5. shortcut setting alpha bands. can override setting alpha band argument. theme Theme name (string) theme function theme_args List arguments passed theme function palette Color palette name palcolor Custom colors palette facet_by Column name(s) faceting plot facet_scales Scales facets: "fixed", "free", "free_x", "free_y" facet_nrow Number rows facet layout facet_ncol Number columns facet layout facet_byrow Fill facets row (TRUE) column (FALSE) aspect.ratio Aspect ratio plot panel legend.position Legend position: "none", "left", "right", "bottom", "top" legend.direction Legend direction: "horizontal" "vertical" title Plot title subtitle Plot subtitle xlim numeric vector length 2 set x-axis limits. ylim numeric vector length 2 set y-axis limits. xlab X-axis label ylab Y-axis label seed Random seed reproducibility

title: ROC Curve Plot ‚Äî ROCCurve
text: wrapped function around plotROC package create ROC curves. ROC (Receiver Operating Characteristic) curves used evaluate binary classification models plotting true positive rate (sensitivity) false positive rate (1-specificity).

title: ROC Curve Plot ‚Äî ROCCurve
code: ROCCurve(   data,   truth_by,   score_by,   pos_label = NULL,   split_by = NULL,   split_by_sep = "_",   group_by = NULL,   group_by_sep = "_",   group_name = NULL,   x_axis_reverse = FALSE,   percent = FALSE,   ci = NULL,   n_cuts = 0,   cutoffs_at = NULL,   cutoffs_labels = NULL,   cutoffs_accuracy = 0.001,   cutoffs_pt_size = 5,   cutoffs_pt_shape = 4,   cutoffs_pt_stroke = 1,   cutoffs_labal_fg = "black",   cutoffs_label_size = 4,   cutoffs_label_bg = "white",   cutoffs_label_bg_r = 0.1,   show_auc = c("auto", "none", "legend", "plot"),   auc_accuracy = 0.01,   auc_size = 4,   increasing = TRUE,   theme = "theme_ggforge",   theme_args = list(),   palette = "Spectral",   palcolor = NULL,   alpha = 1,   facet_by = NULL,   facet_scales = "fixed",   facet_ncol = NULL,   facet_nrow = NULL,   facet_byrow = TRUE,   aspect.ratio = 1,   legend.position = waiver(),   legend.direction = "vertical",   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   xlab = ifelse(x_axis_reverse, "Specificity", "1 - Specificity"),   ylab = "Sensitivity",   combine = TRUE,   nrow = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   byrow = TRUE,   seed = 8525,   axes = NULL,   axis_titles = axes,   guides = NULL,   design = NULL,   ... )

title: ROC Curve Plot ‚Äî ROCCurve
text: data data frame containing data plot truth_by character string column name contains true class labels. (.k.. binary outcome, 1/0 TRUE/FALSE.) score_by character strings column names contains predicted scores. multiple columns provided, ROC curve plotted column. pos_label character string positive class label. NULL, labels handled plotROC package. split_by Column name(s) split data multiple plots split_by_sep Separator concatenating multiple split_by columns group_by Column name(s) grouping data group_by_sep Separator concatenating multiple group_by columns group_name character string name legend ROC curve groups. x_axis_reverse logical reverse x-axis, 1 0. percent logical display x y axis percentages. ci list arguments pass plotROC::geom_rocci() add confidence intervals. NULL, confidence intervals added. n_cuts integer specify number cutpoints ROC curve. quantiles predicted scores. cutoffs_at Vector user supplied cutoffs plot points. non-NULL, override values n_cuts plot observed cutoffs closest user-supplied ones. cutoffs_at cutoffs.labels passed plotROC::geom_roc(). numeric values, following special values allowed. values methods OptimalCutpoints::optimal.cutpoints(). cutoffs_labels vector user-supplied labels cutoffs. Must character vector length cutoffs_at. cutoffs_accuracy numeric specify accuracy cutoff values show. cutoffs_pt_size numeric specify size cutoff points. cutoffs_pt_shape numeric specify shape cutoff points. cutoffs_pt_stroke numeric specify stroke cutoff points. cutoffs_labal_fg character string specify color cutoff labels. cutoffs_label_size numeric specify size cutoff labels. cutoffs_label_bg character string specify background color cutoff labels. cutoffs_label_bg_r numeric specify radius background cutoff labels. show_auc character string specify position AUC values. "auto" (default): Automatically determine position based plot. single group 'facet_by' provided, AUC placed plot. Otherwise, AUC placed legend. "none": display AUC values. "legend": Display AUC values legend. "plot": Display AUC values plot (left/right bottom corner). auc_accuracy numeric specify accuracy AUC values. auc_size numeric specify size AUC values displayed plot. increasing TRUE score increasing truth (1), FALSE otherwise. theme Theme name (string) theme function theme_args List arguments passed theme function palette Color palette name palcolor Custom colors palette alpha Transparency level (0-1) facet_by Column name(s) faceting plot facet_scales Scales facets: "fixed", "free", "free_x", "free_y" facet_ncol Number columns facet layout facet_nrow Number rows facet layout facet_byrow Fill facets row (TRUE) column (FALSE) aspect.ratio Aspect ratio plot panel legend.position Legend position: "none", "left", "right", "bottom", "top" legend.direction Legend direction: "horizontal" "vertical" title Plot title subtitle Plot subtitle xlab X-axis label ylab Y-axis label combine Whether combine split plots one nrow Number rows combining plots ncol Number columns combining plots byrow Fill combined plots row seed Random seed reproducibility axes handle axes combined plots ("keep", "collect", "collect_x", "collect_y") axis_titles handle axis titles combined plots guides handle guides combined plots ("collect", "keep", "auto") design Custom layout design combined plots

title: ROC Curve Plot ‚Äî ROCCurve
text: patchwork::wrap_plots object list combine FALSE. can retrieve AUC values using attr(p, "auc") combine TRUE. combine FALSE, AUC value plot can retrieved using attr(p[[]], "auc").

title: ROC Curve Plot ‚Äî ROCCurve
code: set.seed(8525)  D.ex <- rbinom(200, size = 1, prob = .5) M1 <- rnorm(200, mean = D.ex, sd = .65) M2 <- rnorm(200, mean = D.ex, sd = 1.5) gender <- c("Male", "Female")[rbinom(200, 1, .49) + 1]  data <- data.frame(   D = D.ex, D.str = c("Healthy", "Ill")[D.ex + 1],   gender = gender, M1 = M1, M2 = M2 )  ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1")  # will warn about the positive label ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D.str", score_by = "M1") #> Warning: 'pos_label' is NULL, value 'Ill' from 'D.str' will be used as the positive label.  ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", increasing = FALSE)  # Multiple ROC curves ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = c("M1", "M2"), group_name = "Method")  ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", group_by = "gender", show_auc = "plot")  # Reverse the x-axis and display the axes as percentages ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", x_axis_reverse = TRUE, percent = TRUE)  # Pass additional arguments to geom_roc and make the curve black ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", n_cuts = 10, palcolor = "black")  # Add confidence intervals ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", ci = list(sig.level = .01))  # Facet by a column ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", facet_by = "gender")  # Show cutoffs ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", cutoffs_at = c(0, "ROC01", "SpEqualSe"))  # Split by a column p <- ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", split_by = "gender") p  # Retrieve the AUC values attr(p, "auc") #>   PANEL COORD group       AUC gender #> 1     1     1     1 0.8779167 Female #> 2     1     1     1 0.9039616   Male # Retrieve the cutoffs attr(p, "cutoffs") #> NULL

code: set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(   x = c(rnorm(250, -1), rnorm(250, 1)),   group = rep(LETTERS[1:5], each = 100) ) RidgePlot(data, x = "x") # fallback to density plot #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.371  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", add_vline = 0, vline_color = "black") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.371  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", group_by = "group") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.378  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", reverse = TRUE) #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.378  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", add_vline = TRUE, vline_color = TRUE) #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.378   # wide form data_wide <- data.frame(   A = rnorm(100),   B = rnorm(100),   C = rnorm(100),   D = rnorm(100),   E = rnorm(100),   group = sample(letters[1:4], 100, replace = TRUE) ) RidgePlot(data_wide, group_by = LETTERS[1:5], in_form = "wide") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.337  RidgePlot(data_wide, group_by = LETTERS[1:5], in_form = "wide", facet_by = "group") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.429 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.367 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.416 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.428

title: Atomic Sankey plot ‚Äî SankeyPlotAtomic
text: data data frame following possible formats: "long" "lodes": long format columns x, stratum, alluvium, y. x (required, single columns concatenated x_sep) column name plot x-axis, stratum (defaults links_fill_by) column name group nodes x, alluvium (required) column name define links, y frequency x, stratum, alluvium. "wide" "alluvia": wide format columns x. x (required, multiple columns, x_sep used) columns plot x-axis, stratum alluvium ignored. See ggalluvial::to_lodes_form details. "counts": format counts provides x. x (required, multiple columns, x_sep used) columns plot x-axis. first element x ".", values links_fill_by (required) added plot first column nodes. useful show links flowed source targets. "auto" (default): Automatically determine format based columns provided. length x greater 1 x columns numeric, "counts" format used. length x greater 1 ggalluvial::is_alluvia_form returns TRUE, "alluvia" format used. Otherwise, "lodes" format tried. in_form character string specify format data. Possible values "auto", "long", "lodes", "wide", "alluvia", "counts". x character string column name plot x-axis. See data details. x_sep character string concatenate columns x, multiple columns provided. y character string column name plot y-axis. in_form "counts", y ignored. Otherwise, defaults count x, stratum, alluvium links_fill_by. stratum character string column name group nodes x. See data details. stratum_sep character string concatenate columns stratum, multiple columns provided. alluvium character string column name define links. See data details. alluvium_sep character string concatenate columns alluvium, multiple columns provided. flow logical value use ggalluvial::geom_flow instead ggalluvial::geom_alluvium. nodes_color character string color nodes. Use special value ".fill" use color fill. links_fill_by character string column name fill links. links_fill_by_sep character string concatenate columns links_fill_by, multiple columns provided. links_name character string name legend links. links_color character string color borders links. Use special value ".fill" use color fill. nodes_palette character string specify palette nodes fill. nodes_palcolor character vector specify colors nodes fill. nodes_alpha numeric value specify transparency nodes fill. nodes_label logical value show labels nodes. nodes_width numeric value specify width nodes. nodes_label_miny numeric value specify minimum y (frequency) show labels. nodes_legend Controls legend nodes shown. Possible values : "merge": Merge legends nodes. one legend shown nodes. "separate": Show legends nodes separately. , nodes x legend. "none": show legend nodes. "auto": Automatically determine show legend. nodes_label TRUE, "none" apply. nodes_label FALSE, stratum links_fill_by, "none" apply. overlapping values nodes different x, "merge" apply. Otherwise, "separate" apply. expand Expansion values axes (CSS-like: top, right, bottom, left) links_palette character string specify palette links fill. links_palcolor character vector specify colors links fill. links_alpha numeric value specify transparency links fill. legend.box character string specify box legend, either "vertical" "horizontal". keep_empty logical value keep empty nodes. x_text_angle Angle x-axis text aspect.ratio Aspect ratio plot panel legend.position Legend position: "none", "left", "right", "bottom", "top" legend.direction Legend direction: "horizontal" "vertical" flip logical value flip plot. theme Theme name (string) theme function theme_args List arguments passed theme function title Plot title subtitle Plot subtitle xlab X-axis label ylab Y-axis label facet_by Column name(s) faceting plot facet_scales Scales facets: "fixed", "free", "free_x", "free_y" facet_ncol Number columns facet layout facet_nrow Number rows facet layout facet_byrow Fill facets row (TRUE) column (FALSE) ... arguments pass ggalluvial::geom_alluvium ggalluvial::geom_flow.

title: Scatter Plot ‚Äî ScatterPlot
code: # Create sample data set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(   x = rnorm(100),   y = rnorm(100),   size_val = abs(rnorm(100)),   category = sample(c("A", "B", "C"), 100, replace = TRUE),   group = sample(c("Group1", "Group2"), 100, replace = TRUE) )  # Basic scatter plot ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y")   # Highlight specific points ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", highlight = "x > 1 & y > 0")   # Size by numeric column ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "size_val")   # Color by numeric column with continuous gradient ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", color_by = "size_val", palette = "RdYlBu")   # Color by categorical column ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", color_by = "category")   # Combine size and color mapping with custom border ScatterPlot(data,   x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "size_val", color_by = "category",   border_color = "black" )   # Border color matches fill color (for cohesive look) ScatterPlot(data,   x = "x", y = "y", color_by = "category",   border_color = TRUE )   # Use shape without fill (solid points) ScatterPlot(data,   x = "x", y = "y", color_by = "category",   shape = 16, palette = "Set1" )   # Split by group to create separate panels ScatterPlot(data,   x = "x", y = "y", color_by = "category",   split_by = "group", combine = TRUE )   # Facet by group (alternative to split_by) ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", color_by = "category", facet_by = "group")   # Log transformation of axes data_pos <- data.frame(   x = 10^rnorm(100, 2, 1),   y = 10^rnorm(100, 3, 0.5) ) ScatterPlot(data_pos, x = "x", y = "y", xtrans = "log10", ytrans = "log10")

title: Split Bar Plot (Waterfall Plot) ‚Äî SplitBarPlot
code: # \donttest{ # Basic split bar plot (diverging bars) data <- data.frame(   term = c("Item A", "Item B", "Item C", "Item D"),   value = c(-10, 20, -15, 25),   importance = c(1, 3, 2, 4) ) SplitBarPlot(data, x = "value", y = "term")   # With alpha mapping to show importance SplitBarPlot(data, x = "value", y = "term", alpha_by = "importance")   # With custom fill groups data$category <- c("Type A", "Type A", "Type B", "Type B") SplitBarPlot(data, x = "value", y = "term", fill_by = "category")   # Custom ordering (by value descending for positive, ascending for negative) SplitBarPlot(   data,   x = "value", y = "term",   order_y = list("+" = "x_desc", "-" = "x_asc") )   # Survey-style diverging bars (e.g., agree/disagree) survey_data <- data.frame(   question = rep(c(     "Q1: Service quality", "Q2: Value for money",     "Q3: Overall satisfaction"   ), 2),   response = c(45, 60, 55, -20, -15, -10),   group = rep(c("Positive", "Negative"), each = 3) ) SplitBarPlot(   survey_data,   x = "response", y = "question",   direction_pos_name = "Agree",   direction_neg_name = "Disagree",   palette = "RdBu" )  # }

reverse gradient fills theme Theme name (string) theme function theme_args List arguments passed theme function palette Color palette name palcolor Custom colors palette alpha Transparency level (0-1) aspect.ratio Aspect ratio plot panel legend.position Legend position: "none", "left", "right", "bottom", "top" legend.direction Legend direction: "horizontal" "vertical" add_point Logical; title: Violin Plot ‚Äî ViolinPlot
text: ggplot object combined plots (patchwork)

title: Violin Plot ‚Äî ViolinPlot
code: # \donttest{ # ============================================================ # Basic Examples # ============================================================  # Create sample data with different distributions set.seed(456) data <- data.frame(   category = rep(c("Normal", "Bimodal", "Skewed", "Uniform"), each = 100),   value = c(     rnorm(100, 50, 10), # Normal     c(rnorm(50, 30, 5), rnorm(50, 70, 5)), # Bimodal     rexp(100, 0.1), # Skewed     runif(100, 20, 80) # Uniform   ),   group = rep(c("A", "B"), 200) )  # Simple violin plot ViolinPlot(data, x = "category", y = "value")   # With title and labels ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   title = "Distribution Shapes Comparison",   xlab = "Distribution Type",   ylab = "Value" )   # ============================================================ # Violin with Box Plot Overlay # ============================================================  # Add box plot inside violin (shows quartiles) ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_box = TRUE )   # Customize box overlay ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_box = TRUE,   box_color = "white",   box_width = 0.15,   box_ptsize = 3 )   # ============================================================ # Adding Data Points # ============================================================  # Add jittered points to show individual observations ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_point = TRUE )   # Combine box overlay with points ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_box = TRUE,   add_point = TRUE,   pt_alpha = 0.3 )   # Customize point appearance ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_point = TRUE,   pt_color = "navy",   pt_size = 0.8,   pt_alpha = 0.5,   jitter_width = 0.3 )   # ============================================================ # Grouped Violin Plots # ============================================================  # Side-by-side violins by group ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   group_by = "group" )   # With box overlay ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   group_by = "group",   add_box = TRUE )   # Custom palette ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   group_by = "group",   palette = "Set2",   add_box = TRUE )   # ============================================================ # Statistical Comparisons # ============================================================  # Compare specific distributions ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   comparisons = list(     c("Normal", "Bimodal"),     c("Normal", "Skewed")   ) )   # All pairwise comparisons ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   comparisons = TRUE,   sig_label = "p.signif" )   # Grouped comparisons ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   group_by = "group",   comparisons = TRUE )   # ============================================================ # Paired Data Analysis # ============================================================  # Create paired data paired_data <- data.frame(   condition = factor(rep(c("Baseline", "Treatment"), each = 30)),   patient = factor(rep(1:30, 2)),   response = c(rnorm(30, 100, 20), rnorm(30, 120, 20)) )  # Paired violin with connecting lines ViolinPlot(paired_data,   x = "condition", y = "response",   paired_by = "patient",   add_box = TRUE ) #> Warning: Forcing 'add_point' = TRUE when 'paired_by' is provided.   # With paired t-test ViolinPlot(paired_data,   x = "condition", y = "response",   paired_by = "patient",   comparisons = list(c("Baseline", "Treatment")),   pairwise_method = "t.test" ) #> Warning: Forcing 'add_point' = TRUE when 'paired_by' is provided.   # ============================================================ # Highlighting and Visual Enhancements # ============================================================  # Highlight extreme values ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_point = TRUE,   highlight = "value > 80 | value < 10",   highlight_color = "red",   highlight_size = 2 )   # Add trend line ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_trend = TRUE,   trend_linewidth = 1.5 )   # Add reference line ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_line = 50,   line_color = "darkgreen",   line_type = 1 )   # Add mean indicator ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   add_stat = mean,   stat_name = "Mean",   stat_color = "red",   stat_shape = 18,   stat_size = 3 )   # ============================================================ # Fill Modes # ============================================================  # Fill by x category ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   fill_mode = "x",   palette = "Pastel1" )   # Fill by mean (gradient coloring) ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   fill_mode = "mean",   palette = "RdYlGn" )   # Fill by median with reversed gradient ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   fill_mode = "median",   palette = "Blues",   fill_reverse = TRUE )   # ============================================================ # Sorting and Orientation # ============================================================  # Sort by mean value ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   sort_x = "mean_desc",   add_box = TRUE )   # Horizontal violin plot ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   flip = TRUE,   add_box = TRUE )   # ============================================================ # Faceting # ============================================================  # Add faceting variable data$experiment <- sample(c("Exp1", "Exp2"), nrow(data), replace = TRUE)  # Facet by experiment ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   facet_by = "experiment",   add_box = TRUE )   # Free scales ViolinPlot(data,   x = "category", y = "value",   facet_by = "experiment",   facet_scales = "free_y" )   # ============================================================ # Wide Format Data # ============================================================  # Wide format input wide_data <- data.frame(   Control = rnorm(50, 100, 15),   LowDose = rnorm(50, 110, 15),   HighDose = rnorm(50, 130, 20) )  ViolinPlot(wide_data,   x = c("Control", "LowDose", "HighDose"),   in_form = "wide",   add_box = TRUE,   xlab = "Treatment",   ylab = "Response" )   # ============================================================ # Complex Example: Publication-Ready Plot # ============================================================  # Gene expression data example expr_data <- data.frame(   gene = rep(c("BRCA1", "TP53", "EGFR", "MYC"), each = 40),   expression = c(     rnorm(40, 8, 1.5),     rnorm(40, 6, 2),     rnorm(40, 10, 1),     rnorm(40, 12, 2.5)   ),   tissue = rep(rep(c("Normal", "Tumor"), each = 20), 4) )  ViolinPlot(expr_data,   x = "gene",   y = "expression",   group_by = "tissue",   add_box = TRUE,   add_point = TRUE,   pt_alpha = 0.4,   comparisons = TRUE,   sig_label = "p.signif",   hide_ns = TRUE,   palette = c("Normal" = "#4DAF4A", "Tumor" = "#E41A1C"),   title = "Gene Expression by Tissue Type",   xlab = "Gene",   ylab = "Expression (log2)",   legend.position = "bottom" )  # }

title: Volcano Plot ‚Äî VolcanoPlot
text: volcano plot type scatter plot shows statistical significance (usually y-axis) versus magnitude change (usually x-axis).

text: data data frame containing data plot x character string column name plot x-axis (e.g., log fold change). y character string column name plot y-axis (e.g., p-value). ytrans function transform y-axis values. Default -log10(n). color_by character vector column names color points . NULL, points filled x y cutoff value. color_name character string name legend color. flip_negatives logical value flip y-axis negative x values. x_cutoff numeric value set x-axis cutoff. negative positive value used. y_cutoff numeric value set y-axis cutoff. Top nlabel points labeled. labels character vector row names indexes label points. label_by character string column name use labels. title: Volcano Plot ‚Äî VolcanoPlot
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(8525) # Obtained by Seurat::FindMarkers for the first cluster of pbmc_small data <- data.frame(   avg_log2FC = c(     -3.69, -4.10, -2.68, -3.51, -3.09, -2.52, -3.53, -3.35, -2.82, -2.71,     3.67, 4.79, 10.14, 5.36, 4.56, 4.62, 3.31, 4.72, 3.01, 3.86   ),   p_val_adj = c(     3.82e-09, 1.52e-07, 1.79e-07, 4.68e-07, 4.83e-07, 6.26e-07, 2.61e-06,     1.33e-05, 1.79e-05, 3.71e-05, 8.93e-04, 9.61e-04, 1.47e-03, 4.35e-03,     4.85e-03, 5.12e-03, 1.90e-02, 2.13e-02, 3.80e-02, 6.72e-02   ),   gene = c(     "HLA-DPB1", "LYZ", "HLA-DRA", "TYMP", "HLA-DPA1", "HLA-DRB1", "CST3",     "HLA-DQB1", "HLA-DRB5", "LST1", "CCL5", "LCK", "MS4A6A", "CD3D", "CD7",     "CD3E", "CTSW", "GZMM", "GZMA", "IL32"   ),   group = sample(LETTERS[1:2], 20, replace = TRUE) )  VolcanoPlot(data, x = "avg_log2FC", y = "p_val_adj", y_cutoff_name = "-log10(0.05)")  VolcanoPlot(data,   x = "avg_log2FC", y = "p_val_adj",   label_by = "gene", y_cutoff_name = "-log10(0.05)" )  VolcanoPlot(data,   x = "avg_log2FC", y = "p_val_adj", y_cutoff_name = "none",   flip_negatives = TRUE, label_by = "gene" )  VolcanoPlot(data,   x = "avg_log2FC", y = "p_val_adj", y_cutoff_name = "none",   flip_negatives = TRUE, facet_by = "group", label_by = "gene" )  VolcanoPlot(data,   x = "avg_log2FC", y = "p_val_adj", y_cutoff_name = "none",   flip_negatives = TRUE, split_by = "group", label_by = "gene" )  # }

title: Word Cloud Plot ‚Äî WordCloudPlot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create sample data with words data <- data.frame(   word = rep(c(     "apple", "banana", "cherry", "date", "elderberry",     "fig", "grape", "kiwi", "lemon", "mango"   ), each = 5),   count = sample(1:50, 50, replace = TRUE),   score = rnorm(50, mean = 5, sd = 2),   group = rep(c("A", "B"), 25) )  # Basic word cloud from words WordCloudPlot(data, word_by = "word", count_by = "count", score_by = "score")  # Word cloud with custom palette WordCloudPlot(data,   word_by = "word", count_by = "count", score_by = "score",   palette = "RdYlBu", palreverse = TRUE )  # Word cloud with split by group WordCloudPlot(data,   word_by = "word", count_by = "count", score_by = "score",   split_by = "group", combine = TRUE )  # Create sample data with sentences sentence_data <- data.frame(   text = c(     "Data science is an interdisciplinary field",     "Machine learning uses statistical techniques",     "Artificial intelligence is transforming industries",     "Deep learning is a subset of machine learning"   ),   score = c(1, 2, 3, 4) )  # Word cloud from sentences (auto-splitting) WordCloudPlot(sentence_data,   sentence_by = "text",   score_by = "score",   top_words = 20 ) } # }

Multiple columns concatenated from_sep Separator concatenating multiple columns (default: "_") Column name(s) target nodes. Multiple columns concatenated to_sep Separator concatenating multiple columns (default: "_") split_by Column name(s) split data multiple plots split_by_sep Separator concatenating multiple split_by columns flip Logical. Whether flip source target nodes (default: FALSE) links_color Character. Color links source ("") target ("") nodes theme Theme name (string) theme function theme_args List arguments passed theme function palette Color palette name palcolor Custom colors palette alpha Transparency level (0-1) labels_rot Logical. Whether rotate labels 90 degrees (default: FALSE) title Plot title subtitle Plot subtitle seed Random seed reproducibility combine Whether combine split plots one nrow Number rows combining plots ncol Number columns combining plots byrow Fill combined plots row axes handle axes combined plots ("keep", "collect", "collect_x", "collect_y") axis_titles handle axis titles combined plots guides handle guides combined plots ("collect", "keep", "auto") design Custom layout design combined plots ... title: Chord / Circos Plot ‚Äî ChordPlot
text: combine = TRUE, returns combined patchwork object. combine = FALSE, returns list individual chord diagrams.

title: Chord / Circos Plot ‚Äî ChordPlot
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(   nodes1 = sample(c("Source1", "Source2", "Source3"), 10, replace = TRUE),   nodes2 = sample(letters[1:3], 10, replace = TRUE),   y = sample(1:5, 10, replace = TRUE) )  # Basic chord plot ChordPlot(data, from = "nodes1", to = "nodes2")   # With rotated labels and colored by target ChordPlot(data,   from = "nodes1", to = "nodes2",   links_color = "to", labels_rot = TRUE )   # With values ChordPlot(data, from = "nodes1", to = "nodes2", y = "y")   # Split by variable ChordPlot(data, from = "nodes1", to = "nodes2", split_by = "y")   # With custom palettes per split ChordPlot(data,   from = "nodes1", to = "nodes2", split_by = "y",   palette = c("1" = "Reds", "2" = "Blues", "3" = "Greens") ) #> Using palette 'Reds' for split_by values without explicit palette: 4   # Flip source and target ChordPlot(data, from = "nodes1", to = "nodes2", flip = TRUE)  # }

title: Process the enrichment results from Enrichr ‚Äî prepare_enrichr_result
text: order use EnrichMap EnrichNetwork functions visualization functions ggforge, enrichment results Enrichr need processed prepare_enrichr_result function. following columns renamed: Term -> Description Genes -> geneID (separated replaced /) P.value -> pvalue Adjusted.P.value -> p.adjust Additionally, GeneRatio BgRatio columns inferred. enrichr's documentation, oddsRatio defined : oddsRatio = (* (D - B - C + ) / max((B - ) * (C - ), 1), overlapping genes; B total genes gene set; C (n_input) genes input list; D total genes background. D provided Enrichr. infer , D = oddsRatio * max((B - ) * (C - ), 1) / + B + C - . Overlap = / B (Enrichr) GeneRatio = / C (ClusterProfiler) BgRatio = B / D (ClusterProfiler) C (n_input), provided, inferred D terms equal. starting inferrence, minimum value try unique genes data$Genes/data$geneID.

"wide" indicates data wide format. "list" indicates data list. "upset" indicates data UpsetPlotData object. "auto" indicates function detect datatype input data. long format data look like: wide format data look like: list format data look like: UpsetPlotData object generated prepare_upset_data() look like: group_by character string specifying column name data frame group data. group_by_sep character string concatenate columns group_by, multiple columns provided in_form "long". id_by character string specifying column name data frame identify instances. Required group_by single column data data frame. specific logical value show specific intersections . ggVennDiagram, default, return specific subsets region. However, sometimes, want show overlapping items two sets. See https://github.com/gaospecial/ggVennDiagram/issues/64 details.

title: Process/normalize data passed to Heatmap() ‚Äî process_heatmap_data
text: data data frame matrix containing data plotted. Based in_form, data can following formats: matrix: matrix rows columns directly representing heatmap. long: data frame long format columns values, rows, columns. wide-rows: data frame wide format columns heatmap rows values, single column heatmap columns. wide-columns: data frame wide format columns heatmap columns values, single column heatmap rows. auto: Automatically inferred data format. data matrix, in_form set "matrix". columns_by one column, in_form set "wide-columns". rows_by one column, in_form set "wide-rows". Otherwise, set "long". in_form format data. Can one "matrix", "long", "wide-rows", "wide-columns", "auto". Defaults "auto". values_by character column name data contains values plotted. required in_form "long". formats, values pivoted column named values_by. name character string name heatmap (used rename values_by). split_by character column name data contains split information split multiple heatmaps. used create list heatmaps, one level split. Defaults NULL, meaning split. split_by_sep character string concat multiple columns split_by. rows_by vector column names data contains row information. used create rows heatmap. in_form "long" "wide-columns", requied, multiple columns can specified, concatenated rows_by_sep single column. rows_by_sep character string concat multiple columns rows_by. rows_name character string rename column created rows_by, reflected name annotation legend. rows_split_by character column name data contains split information rows. rows_split_by_sep character string concat multiple columns rows_split_by. rows_split_name character string rename column created rows_split_by, reflected name annotation legend. columns_by vector column names data contains column information. used create columns heatmap. in_form "long" "wide-rows", required, multiple columns can specified, concatenated columns_by_sep single column. columns_by_sep character string concat multiple columns columns_by. columns_name character string rename column created columns_by, reflected name annotation legend. columns_split_by character column name data contains split information columns. columns_split_by_sep character string concat multiple columns columns_split_by. columns_split_name character string rename column created columns_split_by, reflected name annotation legend. pie_group_by character column name data contains group information pie charts. used create pie charts heatmap cell_type "pie". pie_group_by_sep character string concat multiple columns pie_group_by. pie_name character string rename column created pie_group_by, reflected name annotation legend. rows_data data frame containing additional data rows, can used add annotations heatmap. joined main data rows_by split_by split_by exists rows_data. useful adding additional information rows heatmap. columns_data data frame containing additional data columns, can used add annotations heatmap. joined main data columns_by split_by split_by exists columns_data. useful adding additional information columns heatmap.
